title: Enzyme promiscuity powers plant chemical diversity: A case of prenyltransferases in biosynthesis of quinone derivatives
content: Plants are capable of producing between 200,000 and 1 million natural products (specialized metabolites). Such chemodiversity has emerged, occasionally in a lineage-specific manner, as plants adapted to challenging environmental niches on land (Wang et al. 2019; Maeda and Fernie 2021). How has phytochemical diversity evolved? How do plants develop a new biosynthetic pathway for specialized metabolites? These fundamental questions have been studied using genomics, biochemistry, and metabolomics, with the potential for metabolic engineering in synthetic biology platforms (Maeda 2019).
